case_vignette:
The patient is a 38-year-old Hispanic woman who presents with a 1-year history of a very pruritic rash over her interscapular area. On examination, she has a circular area of slightly hyperpigmented macules in the interscapular region. The patient complains of pruritus but no pain in the area of the rash. The patient has no other medical problems and has no systemic symptoms. She has no relevant social or family history and does not take any medications. The patient is a nonsmoker and does not drink alcohol. The patient is a 38-year-old Hispanic woman who presents with a 1-year history of a very pruritic rash over her interscapular area. question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing a very itchy rash over my upper back area for about a year.
Have there been any changes in the appearance or size of the rash over this period?
The rash has not changed in size, but the affected area has become slightly darker in color.
Do you have any other symptoms, such as fatigue, weight loss, or fever?
No, I don't have any other symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, or fever.
Has anyone in your family had similar skin conditions or any other chronic diseases?
No, there is no relevant family history of similar skin conditions or other chronic diseases.
Are you currently using any medications or creams for the rash, or have you used any in the past?
No, I am not taking any medications and have not used any in the past for the rash.
Final Diagnosis: Lichen Simplex Chronicus
